occurrences.line_text: Importune care of their owne publicke cause;
Yet at the last she will her owne cause right.
Which will her cause in battailous array
To which as they approcht, the cause to know,
Who for like cause faire Belge did oppresse,
Of fayre Irenaes cause with him in single fight.
That night Sir Artegall did cause his tent
And for what cause, tell if thou haue it knowne.
To weet the cause of so vncomely fray,
What cause could make him so dishonourable,
Vpon his steed, for no iust cause accused,
Withouten cause, but onely her to reaue
Therefore to him their cause they best esteemed
To giue faire colour to that Ladies cause in sight.
The cause of all this euill, who was slaine
And for what cause declare, so mote ye not repent?
Lo this my cause of griefe to you appeares;
If that the cause of this your languishment
For when the cause, whence euill doth arize,
That mucky masse, the cause of mens decay,
Sith they that were the cause of all, were gone.
She should it cause be fostred vnder straunge attyre.
She caused them be led in curteous wize
King Ryence caused to be hanged hy
She caused him to make experience
And caused him to be disarmed quight,
She caused her Pauilion be pight;
And caused streight a Trumpet loud to shrill,
He caused them be hung in all mens sight,
Then caused he the gates be opened wyde,
And many causelesse caused to be blamed:
In which they shrowd the[m]selues from causelesse feare;
And said, Deare sonne, thy causelesse ruth represse,
To chaunge loue causelesse is reproch to warlike knight.
To thinke, how causelesse of her owne accord
And causelesse crimes continually to frame,
To Artegall, through pittie of his causelesse smart.
And many causelesse caused to be blamed:
Gan causen, why she could not come in place;
To follow her, that was the causer of their ill.
And mightie causes wrought in heauen aboue,
Be wonne their rightfull causes downe to tread:
To kindle his quencht fire, and thousand causes wrought.
And guide the heauenly causes to their constant terme.
But were for other causes firme and sound;
Welds kingdomes causes, & affaires of state,
And sayd, Now sure this doubtfull causes right
Thou doest not know the causes, nor their courses dew.
To messengers, that come for causes iust:
More in his causes truth he trusted then in might.
But by their trueth and by the causes right:
She causeth them be hang'd vp out of hand;
There where the mouldred earth had cav'd the banke;
Beside Cayr Verolame, in victorious fight,
Of name Cayr-Merdin cald, they tooke their way:
Goe caytiue Elfe, him quickly ouertake,
Of caytiue wretched thrals, that wayled night and day.
And valiant knight become a caytiue thrall,
Had made his caytiue thrall; againe he sayde,
And yeeldes his caytiue neck to victours most despight.
Vile Caytiue, vassall of dread and despaire,
And said, Caytiue, cursse on thy cruell hond,
Vile caytiue wretches, ragged, rude, deformd,
His caytiue thought durst not so high aspire,
Did him attonce oppresse, and vex his caytiue spright.
Why then is Amoret in caytiue band,
This dismall day hath thee a caytiue made,
Where this same cursed caytiue did appeare,
With noyse whereof when as the caytiue carle
Art thou the caytiue, that defyest me,
Whereof thou caytiue so vnworthie art;
That cursed caytiue, my strong enemy,
Abide ye caytiue treachetours vntrew,
At last the caytiue after long discourse,
His artes he moues, and out of caytiues hands
Ye with those caytiues saw, Flourdelis hight,
The wakefull dogs did neuer cease to bay,
Soone as the terme of those six yeares shall cease,
But taught the land from wearie warres to cease.
What is there else, but cease these fruitlesse paines,
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
And trumpets sound to cease did them compell.
To cease his outrage, and him faire besought,
Might otherwise preuaile, or make him cease for ought.
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
Went on his way, ne euer howre did cease,
That your victorious arme will not yet cease,
Ne cease her sorrow and impatient stound,
For day and night it brent, ne ceased not,
Yet ceased not the bloudy fight for ought;
Ne ceased not, till him oppressed hard
When as their sharpe contention he had ceased,
For which I thus doe mourne, and poure forth ceaselesse teares.
Yet ceasest not thy wearie soles to lead,
Perswaded him to ceasse, and her Lord to relent.
Caried with feruent zeale, ne did he ceasse,
Them guyded through the throng, that did their clamors ceasse.
Tho when as he was dead, the fray gan ceasse,
Ne ceassed not, till all their scattred crew
At last when lust of meat and drinke was ceast,
Now after all was ceast, the Faery knight
He ceast, and then gan all the quire of birdes
Her dolour soone she ceast, and on her dight
And when it ceast, shrill trompets loud did bray,
And when they ceast, it gan againe to play,
They ceast their clamors vpon them to gaze;
Ne once to breath a while their angers tempest ceast.
Yet ceast he not for all that cruell wound,
That in short space their malady was ceast,
Yet ceast he not to sew and all waies proue,
The sayling Pine, the Cedar proud and tall,
From lowest Iuniper to Ceder tall,
Whiles sad Celeno, sitting on a clift,
Till through celestiall doome throwne out of dore,
That she him taught celestiall discipline,
Did wonder much at her celestiall sight:
So glorious mirrhour of celestiall grace,
But that she is some powre celestiall?
Not that celestiall powre, to whom the care
Her soueraigne bounty, and celestiall hew,
She heauenly borne, and of celestiall hew.
The heritage of all celestiall grace.
Or such as that celestiall Psalmist was,
But some celestiall shape, that flesh did beare:
Did worship her as some celestiall vision.
Then was there heard a most celestiall sound,
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
Ne can the man, that moulds in idle cell,
And to her chamber went like solitary cell.
So taking them apart into his cell,
And searched all their cels and secrets neare;
Was sent to Aganip of Celtica.
By sea to haue bene fro[m] the Celticke mayn-land brought.
Vppon her thigh her Cemitare was tide,
With her sharpe Cemitare at him she flew,
Like coles, that through a siluer Censer sparkle bright.
The which these Stoicke censours cannot well deny.
Then like a Centaure, then like to a storme,
That to a Centaure did him selfe transmoue.
With Centaures bloud, and bloudie verses charm'd,
So many Centaures drunken soules to hell,
When the bold Centaures made that bloudy fray
Infernall Hags, Centaurs, feendes, Hippodames,
From rudely pressing to the middle center;
And he, that points the Centonell his roome,
But like to warie Centonels well stayd,
The worlds foundations from his centre fixt;
The earth was in the middle centre pight,
Ne can Cephise, nor Hebrus match this well:
I fonder, then Cephisus foolish child,
Before the threshold dreadfull Cerberus
Nor harder was from Cerberus greedie iaw
Then Cerberus, when Orpheus did recoure
Of Cerberus whilome he was begot,
With other diuelish ceremonies met:
Whiles fruitfull Ceres, and Lyï¿½us fat
For both the lignage and the certain Sire,
Then of the certaine perill he stood in,
For hoped loue to winne me certaine hate?
Are written sure, and haue their certaine date.
By certaine signes here set in sundry place
Ne made for shipping any certaine port,
And them awayted there a certaine space,
For he ne wonneth in one certaine stead,
Certaine sad words, with hollow voice and bace,
Her certaine losse, if not her sure decay:
Till triall doe more certaine truth bewray.
By chance he certaine miniments forth drew,
That euery one doe know their certaine bound,
For certaine losse of so great expectation.
The certaine cause of Artegals detaine;
There she continu'd for a certaine space,
And leueld all against one certaine place,
By certaine signes he plainely him descryde,
A certaine herbe from thence vnto him brought,
Gan mutter close a certaine secret charme,
Ne ought was feared of his certaine harmes:
And certaine of the theeues there by them left,
That he by them might certaine tydings weene
Directs her course vnto one certaine cost,
Most certaine markes, (sayd she) do me it teach,
She found at last by very certaine signes,
And with the second stroke, thought certainely
Do lurke, thou certainly to me areed,
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
Are not firme land, nor any certein wonne,
Certes, Madame, ye haue great cause of plaint,
Certes (said he) hence shall I neuer rest,
False traytour certes (said the Faerie knight)
Certes (saide she) I wote not how he hight,
Certes (said he) well mote I shame to tell
Ne certes Sir striue you it to withstand,
Certes, my Lord, (said he) that shall I soone,
Certes (said he) I n'ill thine offred grace,
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
Certes (then said the Prince) I God auow,
That certes it great pittie was to see
Certes (said she) then bene ye sixe to blame,
Certes ye misauised beene, t'vpbrayd
And certes seemes bestowed not amis:
Certes I should be loth thee to molest:
Ne certes daughter that same warlike wize
Now certes swaine (said he) such one I weene,
Certes was but a common Courtisane,
Then is your sorrow, certes if not more;
Certes me seemes bene not aduised well,
Ne certes can that friendship long endure,
Braue Knights and Ladies, certes ye doe wrong
But certes his right name was otherwize,
Ne certes wonder; for no powre of man
Certes (sayd he) ye mote as now excuse
Certes some hellish furie, or some feend
He thus bespake; Certes Sir Artegall,
To whom thus Britomart, Certes Sir knight,
Great cause of sorrow certes Sir ye haue:
But certes was with milke of Wolues and Tygres fed.
Certes sir Knight[s], ye seemen much to blame,
Certes her losse ought me to sorrow most,
Certes your strife were easie to accord,
Certes Clarinda, not of cancred will,
Certes (sayd she) sith ye so well haue spide
To whom the Prince; Certes me needeth more
Certes I wote not well (the Prince then sayd)
To whom thus Artegall; Certes Sir knight,
Certes (said he) loth were I to haue broken
Certes Sir knight (sayd she) full loth I were
Well may I certes such an one thee read,
I may not certes without blame denie;
The which was certes in great ieopardy,
And certes it hath oftentimes bene seene,
For certes he was borne of noble blood,
Certes (sayd then the Prince) the God is iust,
That certes I your happinesse enuie,
Ne certes mote he greatly blamed be,
Yet was she certes but a countrey lasse,
For naturall affection soone doth cesse,
That goodly belt was Cestus hight by name,
Without full point, or other Cesure right,
Did chace away sweet sleepe from sluggish eye,
That wont in charet chace the foming Bore;
With all her band was following the chace,
Inflamed was to follow beauties chace,
Or when the flying Libbard she did chace,
Through woods and plaines so long I did her chace,
Yet in the chace was slaine of them, that fled:
When as the Russian him in fight does chace)
Would not so lightly follow beauties chace,
The saluage beast embost in wearie chace,
Whom late in chace of beautie excellent
She on a day, as she pursewd the chace
By this her Damzels, which the former chace
After late chace of their embrewed game,
Your glory set, to chace the saluage beasts,
But with like fiercenesse did ensew the chace:
As a dismayed Deare in chace embost,
Which he in chace endured hath, now nigh breathlesse.
Was thrild with inward griefe, as when in chace
Harts grief, and bitter gall away to chace,
It so befell, as oft it fals in chace,
This gentle crew gan from their eye-lids chace
His cleared heart eftsoones away gan chace
So cruelly did him pursew and chace,
That following his chace in dewy morne,
To follow him; for he was swift in chace.
To saluage chace, where I thereon may hit
After his chace on woodie Cynthus donne:
To hunt the saluage chace amongst my peres,
Who was more light of foote and swift in chace,
And like a wilde goate round about did chace,
So that at length, after long weary chace,
(For he was swift as any Bucke in chace)
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
Still looking after him, that did him chace;
But cruelty and hardnesse from you chace,
There on a day as he pursew'd the chace,
As thou vnhappy, which them thence didst chace,
And chaced her, that fast from him did fly;
faire Florimell is chaced:
To that faire Damzell: Him he chaced long
And who that was, which chaced her along the lands.
And hatefull outrage long him chaced thus;
Then did he take that chaced Squire, and layd
Were deckt with smyles, that all sad humors chaced,
And chaced quite out of the field, that none
And like wyld Goates them chaced all about,
And chaced them both ouer hill and dale:
He him pursu'd and chaced through the plaine,
He followed fast, and chaced him so nie,
Through which the Monckes he chaced here & there.
Britomart chaceth Ollyphant,
Now cuffling close, now chacing to and fro,
From chacing him, till he had it attchieued?
She gan a fresh to chafe, and grieue in euery vaine.
Ne chaffar words, prowd courage to prouoke,
Like scattred chaffe, the which the wind away doth fan.
Which when they all beheld they chaft and rag'd,
Haue knit themselues in Venus shamefull chaine;
O Goodly golden chaine, wherewith yfere
And boasts, in beauties chaine not to be bound,
She held a great gold chaine ylincked well,
To catchen hold of that long chaine, thereby
And with that golden chaine of concord tyde.
At last that mightie chaine, which round about
With that great chaine, wherewith not long ygo
Then that of Amorets hart-binding chaine,
And that great golden chaine quite to diuide,
Hath linckt with me in the same chaine attone?
And with a litle golden chaine about it bound.
With a strong yron chaine and coller bound,
And thereunto a great long chaine he tight,
Against his will fast bound in yron chaine,
Or fault of men, he broke his yron chaine,
As chained Beare, whom cruell dogs do bait,
The which I found sure lockt and chained fast.
But dreadfull Furies, which their chaines haue brast,
Emprisond was in chaines remedilesse,
Infernall furies, with their chaines vntide.
In chaines of lust and lewd desires ybound,
Guyon does Furor bind in chaines,
With hundred yron chaines he did him bind,
And thralled her in chaines with strong effort,
Throwing away her broken chaines and bands,
But her in chaines of adamant he tyde;
And there such ghastly noise of yron chaines,
Faire Amoret must dwell in wicked chaines,
Cold yron chaines, with which let him be tide;
In yron chaines, of liberty bereft,
And bound him hand and foote with yron chains.
Aboue the shynie Cassiopeias chaire,
Great Iunoes golden chaire, the which they say
The fowle Duessa, next vnto the chaire
Of turtle doues, she sitting in an yuorie chaire.
Amidst them all he in a chaire was set,
But lapped vp her silken leaues most chaire,
In hast she from her lofty chaire descended,
And by the rest did set in sumptuous chaire,
And his redeemer chalengd for his foe,
That chaleng'd ought in Florimell, saue they alone.
doth chalenge him to fight.
The stricke[n] Deare doth chalenge by the bleeding wound.
Not to debate the chalenge of your right,
And boastfull chalenge, wexed inlie wroth,
That did her win and free from chalenge set:
Will chalenge yond same other for my fee:
He made him open chalenge, and thus boldly sayd.
Against all those, that chalenge it to gard,
Bold was the chalenge, as himselfe was bold,
These three that hardie chalenge tooke in hand,
Assembled were in field, the chalenge to define.
All arm'd to point his chalenge to abet:
Her to demaund, and chalenge as their rights,
To whom each one his chalenge should disclame,
To chalenge all in right of Florimell,
Did chalenge Calidore to wrestling game:
From euery worke he chalenged essoyne,
For which he chalenged the thiefe to fight.
Which doen the doughty chalenger came forth,
Then gan the part of Chalengers anew
And that late weaker band of chalengers relieued.
And chalenging the Virgin as his dew.
That challenge did too peremptory seeme,
To challenge her anew, as his owne prize,
But she that wrongfull challenge soone assoyled,
And rather chose his challenge off to breake,
Where falling downe, his challenge he releast:
Both challenge it with equall greedinesse:
Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
Did scorne the challenge of so base a thrall:
But both his challenge and him selfe contemned,
Met him in chase, but he it challenge would,
And here arriuing, strongly challenged
Till then your challenges ye may prolong;
And sacred lampe in secret chamber hide,
His chamber was dispainted all within,
And all the chamber filled was with flyes,
That chamber seemed ruinous and old,
His chamber all was hangd about with rolles,
Who through a Chamber long and spacious,
Of that great chamber, should be labour lost:
So was that chamber clad in goodly wize,
And to the troubled chamber all in armes did throng.
And to her watry chamber swiftly carry him.
Chamber are displayd,
About the chamber with that Damozell,
Into a long large chamber, which was sield
And to her chamber went like solitary cell.
Towards her chamber; at which dreadfull stound
With that there came vnto her chamber dore
At last he vp into the chamber came,
Into the chamber, where that Dame remayned
Which doen, the Chamberlain Slowth did to rest them call.
And gazing on that Chambers ornament,
And wau'd vpon, like water Chamelot,
That on their rustie bits did champ, as they were wood.
Then foming tarre, their bridles they would champe,
In the wide champian of the Ocean plaine:
Amid the thickest woods. The Champion stout
The Lady when she saw her champion fall,
To seeke her strayed Champion, if she might attaine.
And that wilde Champion wayting her besyde:
Or heard abroad of that her champion trew,
Her champion stout, and for to ayde his frend,
Which when that Champion heard, with percing point
Not that great Champion of the antique world,
Being arriued, where that champion stout
He now this Ladies champion chose for loue to fight.
Her succourd eke the Champion of the bloudy Crosse.
That her all Greece with many a champion bold
The Champion of true Iustice Artegall.
Him entertayn'd, and did her champion chose:
A Champion, that had with his Champion fought,
A Champion, that had with his Champion fought,
By which if that no champion doe appeare,
Hath he her lent, a Champion to prouide?
And by good fortune the plaine champion wonne:
The whiles the Championesse now entred has
Then laid the noble Championesse strong hond
The Championesse, now seeing night at dore,
So did the Championesse those two there strow,
The Championesse them greeting, as she could,
He spide with that same Faery champions page,
Her lowd gainsaid, and both their champions bad
Those Champions broke on them, that forst them fly,
champions are defaced.
And those six Knights that Ladies Champions,
Those two great cha[m]pions did attonce pursew
For the braue youthly Champions to assay,
Got these three louely babes, that prov'd three cha[m]pions bold.
These warlike Champions all in armour shine,
Thereat the Champions both stood still a space,
Those warlike champions both together chose,
So these two champions to the ground were feld,
And eke her champions glorie sounded ouer all.
It was my chance (my chance was faire and good)
It was my chance (my chance was faire and good)
That feared chance from her to turne away;
And said, Faire sonne, God giue you happie chance,
What direfull chance, armd with reuenging fate,
May meet againe, and each take happie chance.
Now falne into their fellowship by chance,
By chance he certaine miniments forth drew,
By fortune in that place did chance to light:
Subiect to fortunes chance, still chaunging new;
That this young Mayd, whom chance to her presents
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
Weake body well is chang'd for minds redoubled forse.
That now had chang'd her former wonted hew:
She chang'd that threatfull mood, & mildly gan entreat.
As he was wont, and chang'd from hand to hand,
And pitty her sad plight, so chang'd from pleasaunt hew.
In choice, and change of thy deare loued Dame,
That suddein change she strange aduenture thought.
To change her hew, and sundry formes to don,
For that had might to change the hearts of men
Fro loue to hate, a change of euill choise:
Made her to change her hew, and hidden loue t'appeare.
Wonder it is that sudden change to see:
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
Shew'd change of better cheare: so sore a breach
Ne ought mote make him change his wonted tenor,
That all men much admyrde her change, and spake her praise.
Would change his liking, and new Lemans proue:
There gan they change their sides, and new parts take;
If wind and tide doe change, their courses change anew.
If wind and tide doe change, their courses change anew.
Would change with me; but I did it denye;
Yet for no pitty would he change the course
And mongst them al no change hath yet beene found.
All change is perillous, and all chaunce vnsound.
To change his shield with him, to be better hid.
Therewith she gan at first to change her mood,
By change of place seeking to ease her paine;
But by the change of her vnchearefull looke,
That by your change of cheare is easie for to see.
Could ought on earth so wondrous change haue wrought,
Then hoping that the change of aire and place
Would change her paine, and sorrow somewhat ease,
Or change of loue for any worlds delight?
For now three Moones haue cha[n]ged thrice their hew,
So euery place seem'd painefull, and ech changing vaine.
And changing all that forme of common weale,
And blames for changing shield:
Through euery channell running one might see;
An huge eternall Chaos, which supplyes
The hideous Chaos keepes, their dreadfull dwelling is.
As if in stead thereof they Chaos would restore.
A Chapelet of sundry flowers she wore,
There was an holy Chappell edifyde,
On top whereof a sacred chappell was,
Built a faire Chappell, and an Altar framed
And nigh thereto a little Chappell stoode,
Which would not let me be her Chappellane,
Whose character in th'Adamantine mould
And writing strange characters in the ground,
Figuring straunge characters of his art,
With liuing bloud he those characters wrate,
Before the dore her yron charet stood,
So lay him in her charet, close in night concealed.
Their mournefull charet, fild with rusty blood,
